Can you guys please drop the link to any recent papers on NeuroEvolution
th=
at are aimed at replacing or modifying back-propagation? Also if you've
com=
e across any recent papers on game theory, please drop down the links.
Than=
ks in advance.

On Tue, Oct 17, 2017 at 9:15 AM, sean_c4s@... [neat] =
<
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
> Another thing I have found empiricall=
y is to make the networks wider than
> the input vector.
> If the input vec=
tor has say 1024 elements you might want to use a 2048 or
> 4096 sized net,=
 and copy the input data 2 or 4 times to fill the input to
> the net.
> The=
 reason would seem to be information loss caused by the nonlinear
> activat=
ion function.
> You can loose more information per layer than can be compen=
sated for by
> the computation done by that layer.  This is why you see thi=
ngs like
> resnets where they constantly reintroduce information.
> I'll ma=
ybe post some Java code of what seems to be working best.
> 
>

--f403043961245dc1b8055bbe782d

<div id=3D"m_5211801527341472786ygrp-mlmsg">
  <div id=3D"=
m_5211801527341472786ygrp-msg">


    <div id=3D"m_5211801527341472786ygrp-=
text">
      
      
      <p>Another thing I have found empirically is to =
make the networks wider than the input vector.<br>If the input vector has s=
ay 1024 elements you might want to use a 2048 or 4096 sized net, and copy t=
he input data 2 or 4 times to fill the input to the net. <br>The reason wou=
ld seem to be information loss caused by the nonlinear activation function.=
<br>You can loose more information per layer than can be compensated for by=
 the computation done by that layer.=C2=A0 This is why you see things like =
resnets where they constantly reintroduce information.<br>I'll maybe po=
st some Java code of what seems to be working best.=C2=A0</p>

    </div><s=
pan class=3D"">
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;height:0"></div>

=

</div>



  






</blockquote></div><br></div>
